intro: Orthocarpus cuspidatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved orthocarpus, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its umbellate inflorescence. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid regions. Its leaves are narrow and often have a distinct, aromatic scent. The fruit is a small, dry schizocarp that splits into two parts when mature.
